newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swaps - Gas oil down on West selloff.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swaps - Gas oil down on West selloff.

text.p: Singapore gas oil swaps dipped slightly late afternoon on Monday due to a selloff in the West which dampened sentiment, traders said.
"Gas oil is down slightly this afternoon because of the selloff in the West. Nothing has changed over here," one trader said.
September gas oil was last quoted down five cents from this morning at $23.15/$23.25 per barrel, brokers said. It traded earlier in the day at $23.15, they said.
In the west, October Brent last traded down 17 cents to $18.82 per barrel with September gas oil down $2.25 per tonne to $169.00 on the International Petroleum Exchange in London.
The September/October spread traded earlier in the day at minus 74 and 75 cents which is about five cents below its Friday's value.
Despite the slight narrowing of the contango, it is still steep enough to make it worthwhile for oil companies to store their gas oil and jet fuel for winter.
But it had at the same time forced some companies to sell at big discounts in order to make room for fresh cargoes.
In the physical market, one 150,000-barrel cargo for September 2-6 lifting traded at $22.40 per barrel, free-on-board basis, down 10 cents from last Monday's traded level.
Jet fuel is also under pressure with the September regrade slipping to trade on Friday at 80 cents, lower than Thursday's $0.90/$1.10, brokers said.
September regrade was last quoted at 70-90 cents, they said.
Outright September Kerosene traded earlier in the day at $24.00 per barrel, which still yields an implied 80-cent regrade value, brokers said.
Physical jet fuel traded on Friday at $22.80 per barrel free-on-board Singapore basis.
Singapore fuel oil swaps were steady despite the selloff in the west as the market looked to physical buying interest later in the day.
September fuel oil swaps were last quoted 25 cents higher from Friday at $103.75/$104.50 per tonne with October up 50 cents at $104.25/$105.00, brokers said.
September traded earlier in the day at $104.00 and October at $104.50, they said.
